sentences: John Burton Davis Jr. (December 2, 1924 – July 27, 2016) was an American cartoonist and illustrator, known for his advertising art, magazine covers, film posters, record album art and numerous comic book stories.
He was one of the founding cartoonists for Mad in 1952.
Davis was born December 2, 1924, in Atlanta, Georgia.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Davis saw comic book publication at the age of 12 when he contributed a cartoon to the reader's page of Tip Top Comics No. 9 (December 1936).
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: After drawing for his high school newspaper and yearbook, he spent three years in the U.S. Navy, where he contributed to the daily Navy News.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: After drawing for his high school newspaper and yearbook, he spent three years in the U.S. Navy, where he contributed to the daily Navy News.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: After graduation, he was a cartoonist intern at The Atlanta Journal, and he worked one summer inking Ed Dodd's Mark Trail comic strip, a strip which he later parodied in Mad as Mark Trade.
section: == Career == | === Early work ===

sentences: In 1949, he illustrated a Coca-Cola training manual, a job that gave him enough money to buy a car and drive to New York.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: Attending the Art Students League of New York, he found work with the Herald Tribune Syndicate as an inker on Leslie Charteris's The Saint comic strip, drawn by Mike Roy in 1949–1950.
section: == Career == | === Comic strips and comic books ===

sentences: After rejections from several comic book publishers, he began freelancing for William Gaines' EC Comics in 1950, contributing to Tales from the Crypt, The Vault of Horror, The Haunt of Fear, Frontline Combat, Two-Fisted Tales, Piracy, Incredible Science Fiction, Crime Suspenstories, Shock Suspenstories and Terror Illustrated.

sentences: The editors, William M. Gaines, Albert B. Feldstein and Harvey Kurtzman, have said he was the fastest artist they had in those days, completely penciling and inking three or more pages a day at times.

sentences: Davis first worked with TV Guide in 1965, which hired him to illustrate an expansive eight-page advertising supplement for NBC's TV lineup, which featured icons such as Johnny Carson, Dean Martin and fictional characters such as Dr. Kildare, Napoleon Solo and Maxwell Smart.
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: His first cover for the magazine came in 1968, when he depicted a tribute to Andy Griffith, in which the actor was hoisted on the shoulders of his costars, Don Knotts and Jim Nabors.
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: Davis would contribute 23 covers for TV Guide between 1968 and 1981.
section: == Career == | === Advertising and magazines ===

sentences: In 2013 the magazine honored him in a retrospective in which it recounted his history with the publication and spotlighted some of his most memorable covers, including those depicting Rowan & Martin's Laugh-In (March 28, 1970), Davis' childhood hero Bob Hope for a cover on Hope's history with the Oscars (April 10, 1971) and Bonanza (August 14, 1971).

sentences: Following his professional career in New York, Davis and his wife Dena moved to St. Simons Island, Georgia in the 1990s.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: They raised two children: daughter Katie Davis Lloyd and son Jack Davis III, who gave the cause of his father's death on July 27, 2016 at age 91 as complications from a stroke.
section: == Personal life and death ==

sentences: Davis was inducted into the Will Eisner Hall of Fame in 2003.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: He also received the National Cartoonists Society's Milton Caniff Lifetime Achievement Award in 1996.
section: == Awards and exhibitions ==

sentences: A finalist for inclusion in the Jack Kirby Hall of Fame in 1990, 1991 and 1992, he received the National Cartoonists Society's Advertising Award for 1980 and their Reuben Award for 2000.
